global_flags.description: n is a non-negative decimal number, refer to the file de‐ scriptor n and not to a file with that name.

‘~/.gnupg’.   It  is  only recognized  when  given  on the command line.  It also overrides any home  directory  stated  through  the  environment  variable ‘GNUPGHOME’ or (on Windows systems) by means of the Registry en‐ try HKCU\Software\GNU\GnuPG:HomeDir.

normally  checks that the timestamps associated with keys and signatures have plausible values. However, sometimes a  sig‐ nature  seems  to  be  older than the key due to clock problems. This option turns these checks into warnings.

If file begins with  a  tilde and  a  slash,  these are replaced by the HOME directory. If the filename does not contain a slash, it is assumed to  be  in  the home-directory ("~/.gnupg" if --homedir is not used).
to  file file.  Use ‘socket://’ to log to socket.

This option can be used to get the signed text from a cleartext or binary signa‐ ture;  it  also  works for detached signatures, but in that case this option is in general not useful.   Note  that  an  existing file will be overwritten.
Try to be as quiet as possible.
special status strings to the file descriptor n.  See the file DETAILS in the documentation for a listing of them.
Gives more information during processing. If used twice, the in‐ put data is listed in detail.

the  specified digest algorithm as weak.  Signatures made over weak digests algorithms are normally rejected. This  option can  be supplied multiple times if multiple algorithms should be considered weak.  MD5 is always considered weak,  and  does  not need to be listed explicitly.
